title: Osborne Urges Labour Rebels To Back Him
text:

Wed, Oct 14, 2015, 08:04 BST - UK Markets close in 8 hrs 26 mins Osborne Urges Labour Rebels To Back Him By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News â€“ 19 minutes ago View Photo 

George Osborne has urged Labour MPs to defy their leadership and back his plans for a fiscal charter. 
The Chancellor wants to enshrine deficit reduction in law, a policy that has sparked a war of words in the Labour party after shadow chancellor John McDonnell performed a U-turn on the issue. 
After initially saying he would back the idea of running a surplus by 2019/20 and every year thereafter, Mr McDonnell said he had a "change of heart" after visiting the families of steelworkers in Redcar who have lost their jobs . 
:: What Is The Fiscal Charter? 
Some of the party's MPs branded the turn of events an "absolute shambles", and Mr Osborne has called on Labour members to opt for "economic sanity" when the charter is voted on later today. 
He said: "A fortnight ago, Labour told voters they were ready to back our plans. 
"But now, they have confirmed they want to go on borrowing forever - loading debts onto our children that they can never hope to repay. 
"This is not socialist compassion - it's economic cruelty. 
"As Labour's Great Recession showed, those who suffer most when governments run unsustainable deficits are not the richest but the poorest. 
"So today, with Labour's economic policy in obvious chaos, I call on all moderate, progressive Labour MPs to defy their leadership and join with us to vote for economic sanity." 
:: Analysis: Corbyn's Labour: New Politics Or Shambles? 
Defending his decision, Mr McDonnell said the visit to Redcar had made him realise the cuts the Chancellor has proposed and the Government's failure to invest in infrastructure would mean that "people actually are going to suffer badly" and he did not want Labour "associated with this policy". 
He told Sky News that he still wanted to reduce the deficit, and added: "I haven't changed my mind on that, but I have changed my mind on the parliamentary tactics. 
"Originally what I said to people was 'this charter is a political stunt, it is a political trap by George Osborne, it is virtually meaningless, he ignores it himself time and time again, he never meets his targets. 
"So this is just a stunt, let's ridicule it in the debate and vote for it because it's a meaningless vote." 
A number of Labour MPs suggested the change of heart came after Mr McDonnell's economic advisers suggested he take a harder line after the SNP's attack on Labour's anti-austerity credentials and the row over tax credits cuts that overshadowed the Conservative Party Conference.
